SCABBARDANDBLADE
ANNOUNCEELECTIONS
Dr. Ames, Prof. Berry, Dr.
Miles Accept Memberships
8 JUNIORS DESIGNATED
Will Be Initiated After Easter
Holidays
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, Professor
E. W. Berry, and Dr. L. Wardlow
Miles were announced yesterday afternoon as having accepted associate memberships to the Hop:1 chapter of Scabbard and Blade,
honorary military fraternity.
Eight juniors were also designated in the spring elections of the
organization, their pledge ribbons
being pinned on at the regular drill
time by Major McKinney, Professor of Military Science and Tactics at the Johns Hopkins. The
eight named are: J. F. Bledsoe, G.
H. Dowell, E. V. Fineran, S. Linthicum, C. A. Roebeck, E. G. Ruark, F. W. Warlow, and C. E.
Young. Each of these will be a
cadet commissioned Officer next
year, and has been prominent in
military affairs this year.
Initiation And Banquet

Initiation will follow the Easter
holidays and the function will be
followed by the annual spring banquet. The date of the initiation and
banquet has not as yet been divulged.
The Hopkins chapter of Scabbard and Blade, which is known
as I Company, 2nd Regiment, was
installed April 8, 1920, and since its
origin has been very active on the
Hopkins campus. The company is
now composed of eleven active
members.
Purpose of Fraternity

The qualities required for election to the honorary organization
mark it as the ultimate aim of every
R. 0. T. C. student. It has been
the practice of all who attain Scabbard and Blade to attempt to advance the interest in military work
in the institute in which they are
students. The purpose of Scabbard and Blade as is outlined in
the preamble to the constitution, is
"to unite in closer relationship the
military departments of American
universities and colleges; to preserve and .develop the essential
qualities of good and efficient officers; to prepare . . . . as educated
men to take a more active part and
to have a greater influence in the
military affairs of the communities
. . . .; and above all to spread
intelligent information concerning
the military requirements of the
country."
The acceptance of Dr. Ames,
Professor Berry, and Dr. Miles as
associate members of the fraternity
at Hopkins brings the total list of
. Forsuch members to
merly initiated associated members
to the local company are:
Captain 0. 0. Ellis, Honorary,
April 15, 1920; Major Enoch B.
Garey, Honorary, November 23,
1920; Captain Thomas L. MacMurray, Honorary, November 23,
1920; Dr. Frank J. Goodnow, Honorary, January 7, 1924; Major
Gregory Hoisington, Honorary,
January 7, 1924; Captain Fred T.
Bass, Associate, October 11, 1926;
Captain Paul D. Strong, Associate,
October 11, 1926; Lieutenant Robert H. Offley, Associate, October
11, 1926; Major Carl F. McKinney,
Honorary, November 12, 1928;
Captain Eugene P. H. Gempel,
Honorary, July 17, 1929; Dr.
Joseph S. Ames, Honorary, April
14, 1930; Professor E. W. Berry,
Honorary, April 14, 1930; Dr. L.
Wardow Miles, Honorary, April
14, 1930.

KENYON TO TALK ON
"STRANGE INTERLUDE"
Mr. Elmer Kenyon, who is
connected with the Theatre
Guild of this city, will give a
lecture on the "Strange Interlude," and he will include
in his discussion some few remarks on its author, Eugene
O'Neill.
The lecture will be given on
April 28, at 5 P. M. in Levering Hall. After the talk, opportunity will be afforded for
questions and discussions. All
those interested in hearing Mr.
Kenyon are cordially invited
to attend the lecture.

Tomorrow will mark the
appearance of the Spring
number of the Black and Blue
Jay. Among the features of
the issue will be a cover designed by Mr. Thomas Hubbard, instructor of Civil Engineering at the university.
Mr. Hubbard was first art
editor of the Jay in 1921.
Other features of the number
are articles by alumni and several well-known outside contributors.

The Oxford-Cambridge lacrosse
team which is playing a series of
games in this country has in its
ranks a number of men from
American colleges. This team from
across the water has shown marked
ability in its first games in quest
of the International Lacrosse Trophy. The Flannery Cup, and the
players who compose its personnel
have displayed a hard and clean
brand of lacrosse which has received much favorable comment.

WHAT IS THE NEW PLAN DOING?
new Plan has been damned

the beginning of the year, the
SINCE
by two classes of university members; those who are afraid the
extracurricular activities,

Plan will cause a growing diminution of
both athletic and non-athletic, and those who claimed that the Plan
• has proved a failure per se. It is this latter argument that we wish to
discuss.

We have been told that most of the students entering under the
Goodnow Plan have either dropped out a short while after matriculation or have spent their time aimlessly wandering from department to
department without doing any real work or progressing toward a degree. We felt that this change was so serious and, if it were true, so
damaging to the prestige of the Graduate School that we determined
to have a complete analysis made. The NEWS-LETTER is in possession
of figures from fourteen departments of the University that tell the
:whole story. The figures follow:
Number of New Plan students entered first half 1929-30, 27; number of New Plan students entered second half, 27; number of degrees
awarded, 9; number of students dropped, none.
Unfortunately, we were not able to gather statistics for previous
years, but the above figures amply prove that the New Plan, this year,
is in a healthy and flourishing state. No matter if the figures for the
-past years should show less attractive results, we could neglect them,
for the condition that exists today and the prospects for the future are
the only important matters to consider.

ROWLAND HALL

nUR predecessor in office urged that the new Physics Building be
named in honor of the great Hopkins scientist, Dr. Rowland.
• While his suggestion has not been discarded, nothing has as yet been
done toward endowing the latest addition to the Homewood group
with a name.
Calling the new building Rowland Hall would serve a double purpose. It would honor Dr. Rowland, perpetuating his great name. It
would also help toward creating an "identity" for the building, transforming what is now merely a mass of brick and mortar to something
that has a vital, unique existence of its own.•
If the University officials intend to call the new building Rowland
Hall it should be done as quickly as possible, for a habit once formed
is difficult to break and, unless something is done quickly, we shall
go on speaking of the structure as the "Physics Building" long after
it has been officially named. An example is Remsen Hall. Excluding
the younger members of the college most of us still call it the "Chem
Lab" after three years. There is an extraordinarily easy way of keeping
the same duplicity of names from arising in the case of the new structure. It is to start calling the building Rowland Hall now without
waiting for it to be officially named.• Then if it is named after the
great scientist we shall have avoided getting into the habit of speakins of it by another name. If it is not named "Rowland Hall" nothing
will have been lost by using that appelation now since we will then
be compelled only to forget one name instead of another.

R.H.HANNEY

DORM DOINGS
At length the full and entire
forces and evils of Spring are upon
the luckless inmates of the Alumni
Dormitory in the midst of the early
cramming for the coming diabolical
examinations at the close of the
term. Believe it or not, the windows as well as other portions of
the interior of the building are receiving their second semi-annual
cleaning. Perhaps, if sufficient care
and caution is not exercised soon
other more phenomenal occurrences
will be witnessed by the already
astonished residents. Indeed, it
may well be anticipated that ere the

SCABBARDANDBLADE
ANNOUNCEELECTIONS
Dr. Ames, Prof. Berry, Dr.
Miles Accept Memberships
8 JUNIORS DESIGNATED
Will Be Initiated After Easter
Holidays
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, Professor
E. W. Berry, and Dr. L. Wardlow
Miles were announced yesterday afternoon as having accepted associate memberships to the Hop:1 chapter of Scabbard and Blade,
honorary military fraternity.
Eight juniors were also designated in the spring elections of the
organization, their pledge ribbons
being pinned on at the regular drill
time by Major McKinney, Professor of Military Science and Tactics at the Johns Hopkins. The
eight named are: J. F. Bledsoe, G.
H. Dowell, E. V. Fineran, S. Linthicum, C. A. Roebeck, E. G. Ruark, F. W. Warlow, and C. E.
Young. Each of these will be a
cadet commissioned Officer next
year, and has been prominent in
military affairs this year.
Initiation And Banquet

Initiation will follow the Easter
holidays and the function will be
followed by the annual spring banquet. The date of the initiation and
banquet has not as yet been divulged.
The Hopkins chapter of Scabbard and Blade, which is known
as I Company, 2nd Regiment, was
installed April 8, 1920, and since its
origin has been very active on the
Hopkins campus. The company is
now composed of eleven active
members.
Purpose of Fraternity

The qualities required for election to the honorary organization
mark it as the ultimate aim of every
R. 0. T. C. student. It has been
the practice of all who attain Scabbard and Blade to attempt to advance the interest in military work
in the institute in which they are
students. The purpose of Scabbard and Blade as is outlined in
the preamble to the constitution, is
"to unite in closer relationship the
military departments of American
universities and colleges; to preserve and .develop the essential
qualities of good and efficient officers; to prepare . . . . as educated
men to take a more active part and
to have a greater influence in the
military affairs of the communities
. . . .; and above all to spread
intelligent information concerning
the military requirements of the
country."
The acceptance of Dr. Ames,
Professor Berry, and Dr. Miles as
associate members of the fraternity
at Hopkins brings the total list of
. Forsuch members to
merly initiated associated members
to the local company are:
Captain 0. 0. Ellis, Honorary,
April 15, 1920; Major Enoch B.
Garey, Honorary, November 23,
1920; Captain Thomas L. MacMurray, Honorary, November 23,
1920; Dr. Frank J. Goodnow, Honorary, January 7, 1924; Major
Gregory Hoisington, Honorary,
January 7, 1924; Captain Fred T.
Bass, Associate, October 11, 1926;
Captain Paul D. Strong, Associate,
October 11, 1926; Lieutenant Robert H. Offley, Associate, October
11, 1926; Major Carl F. McKinney,
Honorary, November 12, 1928;
Captain Eugene P. H. Gempel,
Honorary, July 17, 1929; Dr.
Joseph S. Ames, Honorary, April
14, 1930; Professor E. W. Berry,
Honorary, April 14, 1930; Dr. L.
Wardow Miles, Honorary, April
14, 1930.

Mr. Elmer Kenyon, who is
connected with the Theatre
Guild of this city, will give a
lecture on the "Strange Interlude," and he will include

O'Neill.
The lecture will be given on
April 28, at 5 P. M. in Levering Hall. After the talk, opportunity will be afforded for
questions and discussions. All
those interested in hearing Mr.
Kenyon are cordially invited
to attend the lecture.

WHAT IS THE NEW PLAN DOING?
new Plan has been damned

the beginning of the year, the
SINCE
by two classes of university members; those who are afraid the
extracurricular activities,

Plan will cause a growing diminution of
both athletic and non-athletic, and those who claimed that the Plan
• has proved a failure per se. It is this latter argument that we wish to
discuss.

We have been told that most of the students entering under the
Goodnow Plan have either dropped out a short while after matriculation or have spent their time aimlessly wandering from department to
department without doing any real work or progressing toward a degree. We felt that this change was so serious and, if it were true, so
damaging to the prestige of the Graduate School that we determined
to have a complete analysis made. The NEWS-LETTER is in possession
of figures from fourteen departments of the University that tell the
:whole story. The figures follow:
Number of New Plan students entered first half 1929-30, 27; number of New Plan students entered second half, 27; number of degrees
awarded, 9; number of students dropped, none.
Unfortunately, we were not able to gather statistics for previous
years, but the above figures amply prove that the New Plan, this year,
is in a healthy and flourishing state. No matter if the figures for the
-past years should show less attractive results, we could neglect them,
for the condition that exists today and the prospects for the future are
the only important matters to consider.

ROWLAND HALL

nUR predecessor in office urged that the new Physics Building be
named in honor of the great Hopkins scientist, Dr. Rowland.
• While his suggestion has not been discarded, nothing has as yet been
done toward endowing the latest addition to the Homewood group
with a name.
Calling the new building Rowland Hall would serve a double purpose. It would honor Dr. Rowland, perpetuating his great name. It
would also help toward creating an "identity" for the building, transforming what is now merely a mass of brick and mortar to something
that has a vital, unique existence of its own.•
If the University officials intend to call the new building Rowland
Hall it should be done as quickly as possible, for a habit once formed
is difficult to break and, unless something is done quickly, we shall
go on speaking of the structure as the "Physics Building" long after
it has been officially named. An example is Remsen Hall. Excluding
the younger members of the college most of us still call it the "Chem
Lab" after three years. There is an extraordinarily easy way of keeping
the same duplicity of names from arising in the case of the new structure. It is to start calling the building Rowland Hall now without
waiting for it to be officially named.• Then if it is named after the
great scientist we shall have avoided getting into the habit of speakins of it by another name. If it is not named "Rowland Hall" nothing
will have been lost by using that appelation now since we will then
be compelled only to forget one name instead of another.
